newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: Zambia maize output seen down 30 pct in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Zambia maize output seen down 30 pct in 1997.

text.p: Zambia's National Farmers Union said on Friday it expected the 1997 maize crop to fall by around 30 percent because of a lack of fertiliser.
"We expect the maize harvest to fall by around 30 percent to 10.8 million 90-kg bags," union president Ajay Vashee told Reuters.
The maize yield in 1996 was around 14 million bags.
Fertiliser imports were delayed last year after South African suppliers witheld supplies until the Zambian government paid its outstanding debts to them.
The government managed to clear the arrears, totalling $10 million, only in October.
Vashee said the drop in maize output would result in a shortfall of up to two million bags, depending on how much was exported.
Under new policies to liberalise the economy, farmers are free to export maize even when the country faces a shortage.
According to official figures, Zambia consumes around 12 million bags of maize a year. However, Vashee said the figure could be lower.
"A lot of people are switching to cheaper and drought-resistant crops such as sweet potato, cassava and sorghum," he said.
Vashee said the union expected fertiliser supplies to increase this year.
"There has been a co-ordinated effort between the private sector and the government to improve the fertiliser situation," he said.
